title: Can I send my finished manuscript to 2 different agents at once? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can send your query letter to as many agents as you want to. Most will only ask for the first n chapters or a certain number of words. If anyone asks for the full manuscript, it generally means they want to read it, so it’s courteous to ensure that two or more agents are not reading it at the same time. Courteous. Not compulsory. I generally advise authors to explicitly give an agent a maximum of 3 months in which to read the manuscript. Most don’t dare to do it explicitly. But even if you don’t tell them that’s your rule, make it your rule. And even if an agent has accepted the full manuscript, keep querying if you find other agents who might be interested.

Only if both have requested it, following your query letter and a synopsis, then feel free to send your ms to two agencies at the same time. If either of them knows you are sending it elsewhere, they may not be happy with your business practices, but if they want your work, they’ll have to deal. When agencies and publishers make authors wait, sometimes for months, even a year or two before making a decision, they really shouldn’t claim a right to individual treatment. One way to hint at what you are doing instead of saying “this is a multiple submission” which most agencies abhor, is to say in your cover letter something along the lines of, “I’d be happy to send you a copy of my full manuscript if you’re interested.” (But don’t use the italics the way I just did.)

You can and I would. Yes, some request an exclusive, but until there’s money on the table, that’s not happening. Unless I REALLY want that particular agent. Then I might consider a two week exclusive, but no longer. Seriously, they can tell within ten pages or so if it’s a fit.

You can send it to as many agents as you want. An agent may request an ‘exclusive,’ if you agree to one, limit it to no more than a couple weeks, like maybe three. And you shouldn’t be above sleazing it. Don’t sent manuscripts unless they request them.
That depends on the agents. If you’ve researched the agents, then you’ll know whether or not the accept simultaneous submissions. Check their guidelines.

Agents will frequently ask for your submission to be exclusive for a period of time. Two months should be the maximum time you’ll wait before sending it elsewhere. Why not look up a few agents and see what their policies are? Some will welcome questions by Twitter. But not submissions on Twitter, I might add.
In the UK, yes, of course you can. You can send to dozens at the same time. Just don’t tell them. Some agents can be very precious.
